page.title: Overview
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-22.mp3

Audio transcript


This section focuses on ways to integrate digital tasks into the areas of creating and communicating information to support acquisition of both English language and digital literacy. In each of the areas of listening, speaking, reading, writing, and vocabulary, the goals are to extend language learning and provide authentic experience with digital tasks in order to create and communicate information. At the end of this unit, you will pick one skill and describe how you might integrate a digital task into one of your classes.

page.title: Developing Listening Skills in English
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-24.mp3

Audio transcript


To support English language acquisition, it is important to provide opportunities for students to listen in English. Students need experience listening in English to topics that are relevant and familiar. At every level, students need experience in listening to different voices, listening for different purposes, and developing listening strategies. Opportunities to listen to the same thing repeatedly and with different purposes and strategies helps students to develop listening fluency. Good listening skills are important in all areas of life, including work, education, family, and community.

Good listening skills are important in all areas of life, including work, education, family, and community.

ELLs need opportunities to listen

  • to spoken English that is understandable,

  • to topics that are relevant and familiar,

  • to a variety of voices and accents, and

  • for different purposes.

They also need opportunities to listen so they can

  • develop listening strategies, and

  • develop listening fluency.

page.title: Developing Listening Skills in English
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-25.mp3

Audio transcript


In the 21st century, real-world listening takes places in person but also in digital spaces. Podcasts and videos are increasingly common ways for people to learn new things in education and work settings as well as to learn for personal enrichment. TED talks, Radiolab, and This American Life are good examples at the time of this writing, but there may be new and exciting digital listening sources when you are working on this unit. Listening in videos, conference calls, webinars, and virtual meetings is also becoming common in workplace and training settings. No one knows what will come next. Since technology is always changing, the digital skills needed for life will continue to evolve.

Developing the skill to access, understand, and learn from oral information on the Internet and in other digital spaces is part of digital literacy.

Part of digital literacy is listening in digital spaces; for example,

  • podcasts and videos for lifelong learning;

  • videos and screencasts in higher education;

  • conference calls, webinars, and virtual meetings for work, education, and training; and

  • many more types of listening in digital spaces yet to be developed.

Tech Tip


Podcasts are audio files that are on the Internet. Many podcasts allow listeners to subscribe so that the regular podcasts are automatically downloaded. Examples of these include weekly radio programs, such as This American Life and Radiolab.

A screencast is a digital recording of what is seen on a computer, with voice narration that is captured with a microphone. The video file is put online and can be accessed through a link. Screencasts are especially useful for showing people how to do things on the computer that are very hard to explain orally.

page.title: Optional Exploration: Listening
page.contents:
If you have never watched a TED* talk or listened to a podcast for your own personal learning or professional development, now is a good time to give it a try. Afterwards, think about your own responses. As a lifelong learner and informed individual, was it easy or difficult to listen and understand? What made it so? Can you imagine that listening online is something that will help your students build listening fluency and digital literacy skills?

*Technology, Entertainment, and Design

 Each box includes a link to a set of online listening opportunities described in "Read more"

The 10 Most Popular TED Talks of All Time

https://www.ted.com/playlists/171/ the_most_popular_talks_of_all

Read more


The 18-minute, high-interest TED talks, called Ideas Worth Spreading, have become a way to enrich lifelong learning. Started in 1984 as a conference where technology, entertainment, and design converged, today TED shares ideas across a broad spectrum—from science to business to global issues—in more than 100 languages.

Audio Files from This American Life, Searchable by Topic

http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/ tag

Read more


These audio files are short (6- to 7-minute) radio stories on a wide variety of topics taken from This American Life, a weekly public radio show that has won all the major broadcasting awards. It is also one of the most popular podcasts in the country, with around 1 million people downloading it each week.

51 Education Podcasts for the 21st Century Teacher

http://www.teachthought.com/technology/ 51-education-podcasts-for-the-21st-century-teacher/

Read more


In January 2013, Te@chThought published a list of 51 podcasts that teachers should consider listening to. As Te@chThought notes in its introduction, podcasts are a way to listen to interesting things while doing other things, such as driving home from work, cooking dinner, or waiting in line.

page.title: Integrate Listening Into Existing Units
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-30.mp3

Audio transcript


As you plan your class, plan to integrate an online listening activity into your units as part of the routine. By integrating the online listening into each unit, you take advantage of the prior knowledge, new information, vocabulary, and grammar that students are already learning as part of the unit. Online listening activities can build on what you are already doing in the unit, which helps to develop listening fluency. Because the listening activity is contextualized within a unit, the purpose of the listening is likely to be clear to the students. There are many authentic purposes for listening, such as to write down a phone message with a phone number, take notes at a recorded meeting to indicate decisions made, and listen for the order of ingredients in a recipe.

Listening resources also offer examples of sentence structure and vocabulary that are being used in the unit as well as examples of the level of formality appropriate for the listening purpose. Teachers can draw students’ attention to these examples.

Help students build both English listening fluency and digital literacy skills by incorporating regular online listening activities into your teaching.  

Integrating online listening into topic-, project- or problem-based units has a variety of advantages, including the following:

  • The content is familiar, which allows students to have more prior knowledge.

  • The information in the listening activity contributes to the students’ growing knowledge.

  • The vocabulary is familiar.

  • Students understand the purpose of the listening because it is related to the unit.

To Go Deeper


Read this article, which describes the ways that several teachers used a serialized podcast in high school classes and the benefits they observed: What Teens Are Learning From ‘Serial’ and Other Podcasts. http://ww2.kqed.org/mindshift/2015/03/11/what-teens-are-learning-from-serial-and-other-podcasts/

page.title: Integrate Listening: An Example
page.contents:
The Arlington Education & Employment Program (REEP) has a series of lesson plans on work and technology. The English Language Listening Library Online (elllo.org) has podcasts on a wide variety of topics.  

There are several podcasts that can integrate well with work and technology lessons:

REEP

Good Work Habits 

Job Duties and Responsibilities

Elllo.org

The Interview

Work Rules

page.title: Listening Strategies
page.contents:
Strategies for listening in both face-to-face and online contexts include

  • identifying the purpose for listening,

  • reviewing what is already known about the subject,

  • predicting what might be heard on the basis of prior knowledge and the context,

  • listening to confirm predictions,

  • listening for language-related information such as level of formality of speaker tone, and

  • summarizing what is understood.

To Go Deeper


To learn more about listening strategies, see Meeting the Language Needs of Today's Adult English Language Learner: Professional Development Module, Unit 3: Incorporating Language Strategies at All Levels of Adult English Language Instruction available here: https://lincs.ed.gov/programs/eslpro

page.title: Activity: Listening
page.contents:
Here are some Internet listening resources that you might use with your students. Take a look at one (or more). For each, think about what might fit well with your units and what supports your students would need to be able to engage in the listening activity.

 

Crash Course

https://www.youtube.com/user/crashcourse/ playlists

For teachers and higher level ELLs. Read more


Crash Course is an entertaining series of 10-minute videos on U.S. History, World History, U.S. Government and Politics, Ecology, Chemistry, Biology, Literature, Anatomy and Physiology, and Astronomy. The spoken language is fast, but the meaning is supported by visuals.

Voice of America Learning English TV

http://learningenglish.voanews.com/media/ all/learning-english- tv/latest.html?z=3613

For intermediate-level ELLs. Read more


Voice of America presents video news stories read slowly, with transcripts available. The video is primarily of a person speaking. Topics include current and world events.

Ello.org

http://www.elllo.org/english/index-recent.htm

For all levels of ELLs. Read more


Elllo.org presents more than 1,200 3- to 4-minute podcasts recorded specifically for adult and adolescent ELLs. The speakers, many of whom are international travelers, have a variety of accents and reflect on a variety of topics. Travel and food topics are common, and there are discussions of education and culture that can complement many English language themes. The recordings are graded for language level and searchable by topic. There are currently a number of podcasts available at low-intermediate level and above.

page.title: Activity: Listening Questions
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-38.mp3

Audio transcript


If you select listening for the activity to complete to earn a Certificate of Completion for this unit, remember that you probably want to start with just one type of new activity. Integrating a digital listening activity into several of your units can be a really good place to start. For this activity, think about the listening resources that you just explored. In your reflective notes or with a colleague, consider the following questions: (1) What units did you identify that would benefit from additional listening practice? (2) What listening resources might fit well with each of your identified units? (3) For each of the units, what is the purpose for listening? (4) What vocabulary items would you need to work into your units? (5) What listening strategies could you model and help students learn to use? (6) What language elements (e.g., level of formality, sentence structures, forms to request information, and so on) will you bring to the students’ attention?

Think about the listening resources that you just explored. In your reflective notes or with a colleague, consider the following questions:

  1. What units did you identify that would benefit from additional listening practice?

  2. What listening resources might fit well with each of your identified units?

  3. For each of the units, what is the purpose for listening?

  4. What vocabulary items would you need to work into your units?  

  5. What listening strategies could you model and help students learn to use?

  6. What language elements (e.g., level of formality, sentence structures, forms to request information, etc.) will you bring to the students’ attention?

This activity is one of a total of five possible activities that you can select to complete for your final activity for this unit.

If you choose this question, share your thoughts with your Community of Practice, or with your colleagues on the LINCS discussion forum.

page.title: Developing Speaking Skills in English
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-39.mp3

Audio transcript


In English language acquisition, it is important to provide opportunities to use students’ emerging language skills, including speaking skills. Much of what teachers do in classrooms involves facilitating spoken interaction between students in the sheltered classroom environment, where students can feel safe to make mistakes. Making mistakes and learning from them is important in language learning as well as in digital literacy.

However, it can be challenging to find opportunities for adult English language learners to practice their new English skills so that they gain confidence to use the skills in contexts that are less sheltered than the classroom but not completely without support. Speaking in digital contexts can serve as an intermediate step between speaking in the classroom and speaking outside of class. There are recorded digital contexts as well as real-time digital contexts. Recorded contexts allow time to plan and revise, which is not possible in real-time speaking, and offer an audience of listeners beyond the teacher and classmates.

In classrooms, teachers provide opportunities for students to

  • practice speaking about issues relevant to students’ lives, interests, and goals;

  • interact with classroom peers;

  • try out new things in a safe and supportive environment, where mistakes are an expected part of learning;

  • practice in situations that are increasingly like
    real-time communication.

Speaking in (recorded) digital contexts can provide

  • practice speaking outside of the classroom,

  • time for planning and revision that is not possible in
    real-time communication, and

  • an audience outside of the teacher and classmates.

page.title: Developing Speaking Skills in English
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-40.mp3

Audio transcript


There are many different ways to increase English language learners’ opportunities for practicing their speaking skills. Voice- or video-over-Internet applications, such as Skype and Google Hangouts, allow for real-time communication with other individuals and groups. These are good options when there are classes that are paired or there is a language exchange program with another school. Paired classes within a program are matched up for activities; often the classes are at different levels. Language exchange programs match up classes learning each other’s languages; for example, a class of English speakers learning Spanish paired with a class of Spanish speakers learning English. Many adult English language learners are very interested in learning about Skype and Google Hangouts because they can use these applications to talk cheaply with friends and family who live far away. These activities greatly enhance digital literacy development.

Speaking in digital spaces is part of digital literacy. Speaking practice can happen in real-time voice (and video) Internet applications such as Skype and Google Hangouts. This

  • provides real-time communication,

  • is good for language exchange programs, and

  • is good for paired classes.

To Go Deeper


To learn more about using Skype for language learning, see Eaton’s How to Use Skype in the ESL/EFL Classroom

page.title: Developing Speaking Skills in English
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-41.mp3

Audio transcript


One way to create opportunities for students to practice their English speaking skills is to have them use the technologies involved in making digital audio files or podcasts. Students focus on spoken English fluency and accuracy as they plan and then record their audio files. Student can learn to monitor their own speaking performance by listening to their own audio file, evaluating it, and revising it. Students can also learn to evaluate each other’s audio files using a rubric or checklist. The exact rubric chosen would depend on the level of language ability and focus of the class. The teacher can assess the final product using the same rubric or checklist, either online or as the students present their audio files to the class. By creating their own podcasts, English language learners become creators of Internet content, not just consumers of it. By putting the digital audio files on the Internet, students are reaching an audience other than the teacher, which helps to create an authentic purpose for their new English language speaking skills. Creating digital audio files helps to develop digital literacy as well as English language acquisition.

Speaking in (recorded) digital spaces can provide

  • practice speaking outside of the classroom;

  • time for planning and revision not possible in real-time communication;

  • an audience outside of the teacher and classmates;

  • an opportunity for adult English learners to be creators of content and knowledge, not just consumers;

  • a way for students to review their own recorded presentations to rehearse and critique; and

  • digital literacy skills.

page.title: Optional Exploration: Speaking
page.contents:
TAFE We Talk graphic Copyright, TAFE NSW

– Sydney Institute, used with permission

We Talk is an example of a student-created podcast developed by new immigrants to Australia. In this 20-minute podcast, two groups of students who went on an outing are being interviewed by a student who wasn’t able to attend.

Listen as they talk about the day, the sculptures in general, and the sculptures they had individually been assigned to write about in more detail.

Pay attention to the purposes for speaking, the vocabulary and grammar used, the interaction between students, and the listening fluency that is practiced.

Note that these audio files continue to be available for listening long after the class is over.

page.title: Optional Exploration 2: Speaking
page.contents:
CREATE A PODCAST

A step toward integrating student-created podcasts into your class is to learn how to make a podcast.

You may be surprised by how easy it is. This screencast demonstrates how to make a podcast. After you watch it, try to make one yourself.

Also see this article by Richard Byrne of FreeTech4Teachers: Some Relatively Easy Ways for Students to Create Podcasts.

Consider your own units and how you can enhance your students’ learning by integrating additional speaking practice using podcasts.

page.title: Integrate Speaking: Examples
page.contents:
As is the case with listening, students’ speaking skills develop most effectively when the teacher integrates speaking activities into units.

Consider the following examples:

  • In a Learners’ Lives as Curriculum® unit on culture, students can tell a story from their childhood. The stories can be made available to children in their community.

  • In a unit on skills for transition to college, students can record interviews with college teachers to find out the most important skills required for success.

  • In a unit in which students learn to make presentations, students record their presentation as practice and for the purpose of evaluating their oral delivery.

  • In a unit on current events and the genre of news reporting, students can create a “news from our class” podcast for a paired lower level English language acquisition class in the same program.

page.title: Activity: Speaking
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-45.mp3

Audio transcript


Here is your opportunity to try it yourself. If you select speaking for the activity to earn a Certificate of Completion for this unit, think about the way that student-made podcasts can enhance speaking in several units in your class. In your notes or with a colleague, consider the following as you develop a podcast creation activity:

List three to four units that could benefit from student-made podcasts.

Who would be the audience for each podcast created? What is the purpose?
How will the students gather the information that they will need to make the podcast?
How will the students plan the recording? This may involve writing scripts or interview questions.
If editing will be required, survey your students to see if any has audio editing experience. If not, what school resources can help?
How will the podcast be delivered to the intended audience? How will the students get feedback from their audience?

Think about the way that student-made podcasts can enhance speaking in several units in your class.  In your reflective notes or with a colleague, consider the following as you develop a podcast creation activity:

  1. List three to four units that could benefit from student-made podcasts.

  2. Who would be the audience for each podcast created? What is the purpose?

  3. How will the students gather the information that they will need to make the podcast?

  4. How will the students plan the recording? This may involve writing scripts or interview questions.  

  5. If editing will be required, survey your students to see if any has audio editing experience. If not, what school resources can help?

  6. How will the podcast be delivered to the intended audience? How will the students get feedback from their audience?

page.title: Developing Reading Skills in English
page.contents:
Good reading skills are important in all areas of life, including work, education, family, and community.

Many of the things that adult ELLs need to read are online, including

  • government information,

  • news,

  • job search information,

  • children’s school websites,

  • entertainment,

  • community event information,

  • product information, and

  • many other materials.

page.title: Developing Reading Skills in English 2
page.contents:
Whether reading in print or online, adult ELLs are learning to read in a new language. There are a variety of reasons for adult ELLs to read in English, including

  • reading as a way to gain exposure to English and build English proficiency;

  • reading for access to information;

  • reading for social connection (for example, social media); and

  • reading for pleasure.

Some adult ELLs will be reading for the first time. These learners are usually learning quite a few things all at the same time, including

  • a new language,

  • the forms and functions of reading, and

  • how to learn in formal settings.

To Go Deeper


To read more about developing digital literacy with learners who do not have literacy in any language (sometimes called LESLLA – Low Educated Second Language and Literacy Acquisition), see Supporting Digital Literacy Development in LESLLA Learners by Reder, Vanek, and Wrigley, available at http://www.leslla.org/files/resources/leslla_2011_Proceedings.pdf. An additional resource on integrating technology for low-literacy English language learners was created by the ESL Literacy Network at Bow Valley College, Canada (visit https://esl-literacy.com/readers/index.html).

Although not about digital literacy, there are several valuable resources on working with adult ELLs reading for the first time, including the ELL-U online course ELL-U: Teaching Emergent Readers (http://lincs.ed.gov/courses); an online professional development learning plan called Working with Emergent Readers (http://literacyworkslincs.learnerweb.org); a classroom video series on teaching ESL to adults (http://www.newamericanhorizons.org/training-videos); a CAELA issue brief called Using Oral Language Skills to Build on the Emerging Literacy of Adult English Learners (http://lincs.ed.gov/professional-development/resource-collections/profile-762); and an article from the Minnesota TESOL journal titled "MAESTRA! The Letters Speak". Adult ESL Students Learning to Read for the First Time (http://minnetesol.org/journal/vol25_html_pages/5_Vinogradov.htm).

page.title: Internet Reading Differs From Print Reading
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-48.mp3

Audio transcript


Reading online is similar to print reading in some ways and different from print reading in other ways. First, Internet reading is often nonlinear—each reader has a unique experience because each selects links to follow, videos to watch, and images to focus on. Second, online reading is multimodal. Whereas in print the reader can infer the relationship between the text and an image, on the Internet the reader needs to differentiate among images that are important to meaning, images that are decorative, and images that are advertisements. Adult English language learners are making this differentiation based on a new language and coming from different cultural assumptions than the website designers. Third, content is unfiltered on the Internet. There are no editors to judge veracity. Instead, anyone can put anything online. Readers need to learn to use a healthy skepticism to evaluate the relevance, credibility, and accuracy of information. For adult English language learners, reading with a critical perspective may be unfamiliar in any of their languages.

Internet reading can be nonlinear. In many cases, readers select

  • links to follow,

  • videos to watch, and

  • images to attend to.

Online reading is multimodal. The readers need to differentiate among images that are important to meaning, images that are decorative, and those that are advertisements.

On the Internet, content is unfiltered. Anyone can put anything online. Readers have to use healthy skepticism to evaluate

  • relevancy,

  • credibility, and

  • accuracy.

(Castek, 2011; Sutherland-Smith, 2002)

To Go Deeper


For more information on critical reading on the Internet, see Unit 3, Digital Information Literacy, of this module located here: https://lincs.ed.gov/programs/eslpro

page.title: Internet Reading Is Authentic Material
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-49.mp3

Audio transcript


When you read on the Internet, you are reading authentic material. Authentic materials are developed for many purposes but are not developed for language learners. Like reading authentic print materials that you might select to use in class, the content of authentic material is more likely to be relevant to adult English language learners because it is selected based on students’ interests and needs. Reading authentic material, whether online or in print, provides exposure to and practice with forms of language needed for out-of-class use. However, authentic material is not graded for language learners. It can have difficult vocabulary and grammar, and it can be visually confusing and conceptually unclear. Authentic material requires support. On the Internet, support can take the form of language support tools such as online dictionaries, translators, and screen readers. Of course, teachers provide support as well.

Reading on the Internet is reading authentic material.

  • Content is likely to be relevant and timely.

  • Internet reading provides exposure to forms of language from the real world.

  • Internet reading provides practice reading authentic language.

Reading authentic material can be difficult because it

  • is not graded for difficulty,

  • may include difficult vocabulary,

  • may include unfamiliar grammar,

  • can be visually confusing, and

  • can be conceptually unclear.

Reading online authentic material requires support:

  • online language support tools, and

  • teachers.

page.title: Reading Strategies
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-50.mp3

Audio transcript


For adult English language learners, the teacher helps to build the vocabulary and grammar around a topic so that when ELLs perform a reading task, they have quite a bit of English to bring to the reading. As it is with teaching English print reading to adult ELLs, teaching online reading requires good reading strategies. Prereading strategies should serve to activate prior knowledge of the topic, identify goals for reading, and make predictions about the content of the reading. In implementing during-reading strategies, teachers can work with adult ELLs to stop and check their own understanding against prior knowledge and predictions, asking questions when they do not match and going back to reread when needed. Reading strategies are especially important for adult ELLs, who need to rely more heavily on prior knowledge and predictions since their knowledge of vocabulary and grammar may not be sufficient to understand nuances of meaning from the text alone; yet, they may be tripped up by assumed cultural knowledge that is unfamiliar.

Strategies that are important in print reading are important in online reading as well; these include

  • identifying goals for reading;

  • previewing the text;

  • skimming for relevant information;

  • asking questions;

  • making predictions;

  • using prior knowledge;

  • focusing on parts of the text that are more important than others; and

  • forming a mental model of the meaning on the basis of the text information, inferences, and prior knowledge.

(Afflerbach & Cho, 2010)

page.title: Internet Reading Strategies
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-51.mp3

Audio transcript


As it is with print-based reading strategies, Internet reading strategies are especially important for adult English language learners, who have the added complexity of Internet reading in a new language. Due to their potentially weaker language skills, adult ELLs need to learn to use Internet reading strategies effectively so they can understand Internet text. When reading online, model reading strategies with your students. Talk through the process of selecting the links to follow, if any. Identify parts of the website that need to be read and those that do not. Read selected parts of the text, moving back or ahead as needed. Keep a focus on the purpose for reading. Model a healthy skepticism, and evaluate the information on the basis of relevance, credibility, and accuracy. Help students to use online language support tools—such as translators, screen readers, and embedded lookup tools—when they are reading online.

In addition, there are several reading strategies that are specific to Internet reading.

In particular, Internet readers often have to select what they read from an overwhelming array of information. Even within a specific resource, readers need to

  • select the links to follow, if any;

  • identify parts of the website to read and those to avoid;

  • read selected parts of the text;

  • move ahead or back;

  • monitor focus on the goals for reading;

  • maintain a healthy skepticism; and

  • evaluate on the basis of relevance, credibility, and accuracy.

(Afflerbach & Cho, 2010)

Online language support tools include

  • translators,

  • screen readers, and

  • embedded lookup tools.

page.title: Integrate Internet Reading
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-52.mp3

Audio transcript


Internet reading is best integrated into the content of an English language acquisition class rather than being part of a technology lesson. Reading Internet information that is part of a unit has many advantages. Since the topic is becoming increasingly familiar as part of the unit, students bring more knowledge to the Internet reading task and can learn more information from it. Internet reading can leverage familiar vocabulary that has been learned as part of the unit. The purposes for reading are also more likely to be clear because it is related to the unit. For example, in a unit on a children’s school, an Internet reading task might include reading a web-based school calendar to find the school holidays and parent-teacher conference days. Activities that follow the reading relate to the unit. For example, for an activity on the cultural assumptions involved with parent-teacher conferences, questions that are appropriate to ask and how to understand the ways that teachers might ask and answer questions might all be appropriate follow-up activities to communicate the information learned from the Internet reading.

It is best to integrate Internet reading into the content of the English language acquisition class as opposed to making it part of a separate technology lesson.

Integrating Internet reading into topic-, project-, or problem-based units has a variety of advantages, including the following:

  • The topic is familiar, which allows students to have more prior knowledge.

  • The reading contributes to the students’ growing knowledge.

  • The vocabulary is familiar.

  • Students understand the purpose of the reading because it relates to the unit.

  • Activities that follow the reading relate to the unit and provide a purpose for communicating the information learned from the reading.

page.title: Use the Same Basic Activity Multiple Times
page.contents:
K

What do you know?

W

What do you want to learn?

L

What did you learn?



Select an Internet reading to include after the unit is well established. There should be related information, vocabulary, and grammar that are becoming familiar to the students.

Activity structure

Introduce the reading and model strategies, such as

  • identifying prior knowledge, and

  • establishing a goal for reading.

Look at the Internet text with the students and model strategies such as

  • previewing the text to make predictions about the information,

  • identifying where the important information is on the page,

  • identifying advertisements and other images for decoration and not content,

  • selecting several appropriate links to follow, and

  • comparing information being read to prior knowledge and predictions made.

Tech Tip


Other kinds of graphic organizers can work well for identifying prior knowledge and establishing a goal for reading as well as for organizing the information that is being read. See a review of collaborative mind mapping tools at http://www.freetech4teachers.com/2010/03/nine-tools-for-collaboratively-creating.html#.VWiOTM9Viko

page.title: Use the Same Basic Activity Multiple Times 2
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-54.mp3

Audio transcript


Continue modeling the process: Read the Internet text together with the students and ask questions out loud, modeling strategies. Ask the following questions and discuss the answers: Does this information answer my question? What links should I follow next? What videos should I watch, and what images should I focus on? Is this information true? How do I know? Do I need more information? If more information is needed, make a plan with the students about how to get it.

Then give the students a turn. Working in pairs or small groups, have the students read the same Internet page that you modeled. This is a good strategy for English language learners because they have already heard and discussed the information once, and now they have a chance to read it for themselves with strong background knowledge. One option is to follow the same links and focus on the same images and videos. Another option is to use the same Internet page but take a different path. This is a good option for students who easily understood the information the first time. Provide support materials that are useful to the students for remembering the strategies. Such materials could be cards with associated images, a worksheet to fill out, a checklist to complete, or another type of material related to the unit.

Read the Internet text together with the students, and ask questions out loud, modeling strategies.

  • Does this information answer my question?

  • What links should I follow next?

  • What videos should I watch?

  • Is this information true? How do I know?

  • Does this information serve my goal?

  • Do I need more information?

Discuss the reading with the students. If more information is needed, make a plan with the students about how to get it.

Have the students take a turn. Working in pairs or small groups, have the students read the same Internet page that you modeled. One option is to follow the same links and focus on the same images and videos. Another option is to use the same Internet page but take a different path.

Provide support materials that are useful to the students for remembering the strategies. The support could be cards with associated images, a worksheet to fill out, a checklist to complete, or another type of material related to the unit.

page.title: Increasing Independence
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-55.mp3

Audio transcript


Students should read on the Internet as soon as possible. They need to make their own mistakes and learn from them, which is part of being digitally literate. For this reason, provide many opportunities for Internet reading, even if the reading is only partially understood. Demonstrate language support tools like translators and screen readers to provide support.

Engage in a similar Internet reading activity at least once in each unit. Routine, familiar activities provide support for learners, which is especially important when they are working with new technology. The next time you have an Internet reading activity, have the students do something that increases their independence. For example: you model only part of the process; the students read a different Internet text but use the same process; or the students engage in one more activity with the reading.

Another option is that the next time you do not model the activity but instead have the learners go straight to it.

According to the level of your students, continue to engage in Internet reading activities that are increasingly independent but that use the same process.

Engage in a similar type of activity at least once in each unit. Routine, familiar activities provide support for learners that is especially important when working with new technology.

The next time you have an Internet reading activity, have the students do something that increases their independence. For example,

  • you model only part of the process,

  • the students read a different Internet text but use the same process, or

  • the students engage in one more activity with the reading.

The next time, don’t model the activity, but instead, have the learners go straight to it.

According to the level of your students, continue to engage in Internet reading activities that are increasingly independent but that use the same process.

page.title: Optional Exploration: Reading
page.contents:
Here are some Internet reading resources. Take a look at one (or more). For each, think about what Internet readings might fit well with your units and what supports your students would need to be able to do the Internet reading. As with all materials, critically examine the content to make sure that it is appropriate for your students and context.

 

MyPlate.gov

A website by the U.S. Department of Agriculture for the purpose of promoting good health.

Read more


The ChooseMyPlate.gov website was created by the U.S. Department of Agriculture to promote good health. The website has many different linked pages and a lot of information in text, image, and video formats.

Welcome to the five food groups would fit well into a unit on food and nutrition for lower level adult English learners. Why is physical activity important? has longer text and many options for additional information that would be appropriate for intermediate-level students.

ESL Literacy Readers

This collection of online readers was created for adult English-as-a-second-language learners who have low literacy and limited formal education.

Read more


The ESL Literacy Readers are a collection of readers created at Bow Valley College, in Calgary, Canada, for adult ELLs who have low literacy and limited formal education The themes have high interest to learners as well as relevance to their lives. The collection includes 12 to 15 readers at each of 3 levels. For example, Deng Starts School and Sado Goes to School would fit in well with a unit on education, while A Problem at Work and Marie’s Path to a New Job would fit in well with many units on work and employment.

Voice of America Learning English

News-oriented stories written in simplified language with supporting visuals.

Read more


This Voice of America website provides news stories on a variety of topics, written in simplified English, using restricted vocabulary. While the target audience is English learners living outside of an English-speaking environment, the Learning English pieces can be useful for adult ELLs in the United States, too. There are no links in the text nor Internet navigation features. However, there are many points for critical reading. The stories available are based on current events and rotate regularly.

CareerOneStop.org

U.S. Department of Labor website with information on jobs, career exploration, and training.

Read more


A website of the U.S. Department of Labor, careeronestop has many different pages. There are a variety of options for navigation, links, images. and videos. For example, a page on identifying the skills that you already have under the Explore Careers tab http://www.careeronestop.org/ExploreCareers/ assessments/skills.aspx provides important information in the text, a variety of links to choose from, several images to evaluate, and a set of videos to link to. It would go well with many units on careers, employment, or training.

page.title: Activity: Reading
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-61.mp3

Audio transcript


You may select reading for the activity to complete to earn a Certificate of Completion. If you do, think about the reading resource(s) that you have just explored. In your notes or with a colleague, consider the following:

What Internet readings might fit well with each of your curriculum units?

What supports would your students need to read each Internet selection?

What are the ways that you would help your students select the appropriate links to follow, focus on appropriate images or videos, and evaluate the information?

How can you support your students’ increasingly independent Internet reading in a way that is appropriate to their level?

What is the best way to support a mindset of “make mistakes and learn from them” in your class?

Describe the activity that you have designed.

Think about the reading resource(s) that you have explored. In your reflective notes or with a colleague, consider the following:

  1. What Internet readings might fit well with each of your curriculum units?  

  2. What supports would your students need in order to read each Internet selection?

  3. What are the ways that you would help your students select the appropriate links to follow, focus on appropriate images or videos, and evaluate the information?

  4. How can you support your students’ increasingly independent Internet reading in a way that is appropriate to their level?

  5. What is the best way to support a mindset of “make mistakes and learn from them” in your class?

  6. Describe the activity that you have designed.

This activity is one of a total of five possible activities that you can select to complete for your final activity for this unit.

If you choose this question, share your thoughts with your Community of Practice, or with your colleagues on the LINCS discussion forum.

page.title: Developing Writing Skills in English
page.contents:
Like English speaking, listening, and reading, writing is important to all aspects of life for adult ELLs. In many cases, the writing utilizes technology and is in a digital environment. Being able to use technology to create and communicate information is an important part of digital literacy.

Adult ELLs need to write for many purposes and for different audiences. The kinds of writing that ELLs may need or want to do include

  • report for work or school,

  • cover letter to accompany a job application,

  • PowerPoint to accompany a presentation at work or school,

  • e-mail to a child’s teacher,

  • professional or personal blog,

  • posts to social media, and

  • many more materials.

page.title: Optional Exploration: Writing
page.contents:
Reading or writing a blog for the purpose of professional development has become a common practice for teachers. If you don’t already read blogs, now is a good time to look at one (or more). It will help give you a sense of blog purposes and conventions of the genre. Consider following one for your own ongoing professional development. Once you are familiar with the genre, consider starting your own blog, by yourself or with colleagues.

 

Tech Tips for Teachers

Tech Tips for Teachers is a blog intended for adult education teachers and tutors looking for straightforward help on integrating technology into instruction.

Read more


Tech Tips for Teachers is produced by World Education, which says that the blog “is intended for adult education teachers and tutors looking for straight-forward help on integrating technology into instruction.” A variety of professionals in the field serve as guest bloggers. An ESL-related blog post, “Open Educational Resources,” was recently posted by guest blogger Jen Vanek. You can read the blog post at http://edtech.worlded.org/blog/

FreeTech4Teachers

The FreeTech4Teachers award-winning blog is a site that shares information about free resources that teachers can use in their classrooms.

Read more


FreeTech4Teachers is a blog by Richard Byrne, an award-winning blogger who wants “to share information about free resources that teachers can use in their classrooms.” Byrne blogs regularly and is best known for his reviews comparing digital tools to accomplish a teaching-related goal. The blog is appropriate for all teachers, but the focus is on K–12. View Byrne’s post on creating blogs and websites here: http://www.freetech4teachers.com/ p/creating-effective-blogs-websites.html#.VSV4KGZkhLE

Larry Ferlazzo’s Website of the Day

Website of the Day is a blog that focuses on English language learning and teaching in a variety of environments around the world.

Read more


Larry Ferlazzo is an award-winning high school teacher who collects resources for teaching English language acquisition. Many entries in the blog are relevant to teaching English language acquisition for adults. In his blog, he reviews Internet-based resources that can help ELLs and their teachers. Best known are his “Best of” blog posts, such as this one: http://larryferlazzo.edublogs.org/ 2013/09/24/the-best-three- sites-on-the-web-for-esleflellelt-teachers/

page.title: Integrate Writing
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-67.mp3

Audio transcript


Writing instruction is most effective for students when they are writing for a real purpose and for a real audience. Because anyone can post anything on the Internet, it is also a place where adult English language learners can find an audience for their writing, whether it is random readers, students from a class that has been paired, family members near and far, or others.

Digital writing tasks can be integrated into established units. The unit provides the purpose and audience for writing that inform design of the activity. Digital writing products can take many forms, including presentations, blogs, and digital storytelling. When you read this professional development module, you may find new ways of writing in digital spaces.

Writing instruction is most effective when students are writing for a real purpose and for a real audience.  

Digital writing tasks can be integrated into established units. The unit provides the purpose and audience for writing that inform design of the activity.  

Digital writing products can take many forms, including

  • presentations,

  • blogging, and

  • digital storytelling.

page.title: Integrate Writing: Presentations
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-68.mp3

Audio transcript


Making presentations is part of education, training, and many types of work; it is, therefore, a valuable skill for English language learners. Presentations can be created by an individual or by a team working collaboratively. There are many authentic purposes for making presentations. For example, in a unit on health and illness, students can create a PowerPoint presentation on a chronic illness that is common in their community. They can deliver the informational presentation to community members or to a different class in their school. At the same time that the students are learning about health literacy, they are also learning about making digital presentations. The quote by Dr. Wrigley illustrates the power that technology can have for adult ELLS in your classes and the importance of being able to speak to audiences outside of the classroom.

Making presentations is part of education, training, and many types of work; it is, therefore, a valuable skill for ELLs. Presentations can be created by an individual or by a team working collaboratively.

“Being able to produce and create projects in English using popular technology moves the work that students do into a different dimension: They now become creators of knowledge; they do work that other smart people do and are involved in efforts that are recognized as important, not just by fellow students and their own teachers but by the “real world” outside of the classroom”.

(Wrigley, 2004, p.4)

To Go Deeper


Read about teachers implementing student-generated presentations in Research in Action: Teachers, Projects, and Technology by Heide Spruck Wrigley. Available at http://www.literacywork.com/Literacywork.com/Resources_files/Research%20in%20Action.pdf

page.title: Integrate Writing: Digital Stories and Blogs
page.contents:
“The rise of blogging as a form of communicative and informational expression has been mercurial.”

(Thorne, 2009, p. 436).

Digital storytelling and blogging are good ways to expand writing opportunities in English and in digital contexts.  Both kinds of writing allow students to use language and visual media for ongoing identity formation and self-expression as well as skill-building.

Blogging and digital storytelling are especially helpful to English language learners because, in the process of reading other blogs and digital stories as preparation to write, adult ELLs can learn the cultural conventions for self-expression in the genre.

For example, in a Learners’ Lives as Curriculum ® unit on the family, students can create a digital story or blog that documents some aspect of their lives that is tied to the unit. Using photos, audio voice recording, and language being created in the unit, even low-level students can create simple stories. The digital story can be shared with other learners, with the community, and especially with the children in the community.

To Go Deeper


Richard Byrne, on FreeTech4Teachers.com, provides several instructional videos to demonstrate how to create blogs, using a variety of different tools: http://www.freetech4teachers.com/p/creating-effective-blogs-websites.html#.VSWfUWZkhLE

page.title: Integrate Writing: Digital Stories
page.contents:
“[Digital storytelling] gives students a chance to practice grammar, pronunciation and oral delivery in a highly motivating context as they share life stories.”

(National Institute for Literacy, 2010, p. 5)

Producing digital stories that combine images and sound, as well as text, provides the support that lower level students need in order to create and communicate information that is important to them.  

To Go Deeper


There is a comprehensive description of how to create a digital story on a wiki called 50+ Web Ways to Tell a Story by Alan Levine (http://50ways.wikispaces.com/) and a comprehensive set of links related to creating digital stories as part of Kathy Schrock’s Guide to Everything (http://www.schrockguide.net/digital-storytelling.html).

page.title: Integrate Writing: Examples
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-71.mp3

Audio transcript


Watch a slideshow presentation by Ruth Gay and Kristi Reyes about the process used in the English language acquisition program at MiraCosta College Community Learning Center as students created their own digital stories. Then, follow the link to see some examples of the students’ digital stories. Watch a slideshow presentation from TESOL 2015 in which Jamey Sadownick from English Language Centres New York describes how higher level students can do a lot with digital stories. Then, look at some examples of those digital stories.

Students at the MiraCosta College Community Learning Center produced a variety of digital stories, which can be found at http://esldigitalstorytelling.blogspot.com/. A presentation by Ruth Gay and Kristi Reyes about the process used to create the digital stories is at http://mccdigitalstory.blogspot.com/.

Higher level students can do more with a digital story, as seen in student stories (https://vimeo.com/ecnydigitalstories/videos) as presented at TESOL 2015 by Jamey Sadownick from English Language Centres New York. Sadownick describes the class that created these digital stories in a Prezi found here: https://prezi.com/rdxicghvssx3/creating-testimonials-with-digital-media/

page.title: Creating an Internet Writing Activity
page.contents:
Design an activity for students (individually or in small groups) and consider the following steps (different steps will be appropriate depending on the student and your context):

  • Generate ideas and/or collect information.

  • Make a plan covering what to include, how to organize it, what language is needed, and the conventions of the genre.

  • Participate in a teacher-provided language workshop for needed vocabulary and grammar.

  • Draft the content.

  • Get feedback from student peers.

  • Revise the content.

  • Get more feedback, and revise again (repeating as necessary).

  • Edit for grammar, vocabulary, and language conventions, such as punctuation.

page.title: Activity: Writing
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-73.mp3

Audio transcript


If you select writing for the activity to complete to earn a Certificate of Completion, think about your teaching and the need to integrate writing in digital contexts into the curriculum. Select at least one or, ideally, two units that could benefit from supplementation of the writing component. On the basis of the unit topic, goals, and objectives, select a type of writing (presentation, blog, digital story, or something else) that can align well. Establish a purpose and audience for the piece. In your reflective notes or with a colleague, consider the following questions:

What unit(s) did you identify?
What type of writing did you select?
What are the purpose and audience for the writing?
What is the writing activity that you designed (see steps on previous page)?
How will you “publish” the student products, and how will you get them to the intended audiences?
How will the students be assessed?

Think about your teaching and the need to integrate writing in digital contexts into the curriculum. Select at least one, ideally two, unit(s) that could benefit from supplementation of the writing component.

On the basis of the unit topic, goals, and objectives, select a type of writing (presentation, blog, digital story, or something else) that can align well. Establish a purpose and audience for the piece.

In your notes or with a colleague, consider the following questions:  

  1. What unit(s) did you identify?

  2. What type of writing did you select?

  3. What are the purpose and audience for the writing?

  4. What is the writing activity that you designed (see steps on previous page)?

  5. How will you “publish” the student products, and how will you get them to the intended audiences?

  6. How will the students be assessed?

page.title: Developing Vocabulary Skills in English
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-74.mp3

Audio transcript


Learning enough vocabulary to be comfortable speaking and writing in English is very challenging for all adult English language learners. They need many opportunities to learn new vocabulary, both in class and working independently. Using the Internet, students can find out how to learn vocabulary while also developing digital literacy skills. Making regular vocabulary presentations is a way that students can learn vocabulary and digital skills as an in-class activity. Another way is for students to create vocabulary notebooks.

Learning enough vocabulary to be comfortable in many English written and spoken environments is challenging for all adult English language learners.  

Adult ELLs need many opportunities to learn new vocabulary, both in class and working independently.

Using the Internet, students can learn how to learn vocabulary, while also developing digital literacy skills.

 

To Go Deeper


To learn more about teaching vocabulary in general, there is an online professional development learning plan called ELL-U Teaching Vocabulary, available at http://literacyworkslincs.learnerweb.org

page.title: Integrate Vocabulary
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-75.mp3

Audio transcript


Vocabulary is one of the most important aspects of English language acquisition, yet teachers devote insufficient class time to it. Adult English language learners need to learn many vocabulary items, and they also need to learn how to learn vocabulary independently. The Internet offers many resources for learning vocabulary. In your classes, you are likely to teach vocabulary as part of your units—and that is a good thing. When students encounter vocabulary on multiple occasions in multiple contexts, it adds depth and breadth to meaning to language acquisition.

However, be careful not to teach closely related semantic sets at the same time. Research shows that students easily confuse closely related words if learned together. The words include opposites (day and night; hot and cold), near synonyms (persuade and convince; goal and aim), and semantic sets like days of the week or items of clothing. So, present closely related items on different class days, and instead, teach items that have a loose thematic or topical relationship.

Learning vocabulary as part of a unit has several advantages:

  • Students encounter the same vocabulary multiple times in different contexts, providing depth and breadth to the meaning.

  • Students are exposed to a variety of related words and the relationships among them, an important aspect of meaning.

In contrast, learning closely related words at the same time makes learning those words more difficult. Examples include

  • opposites, such as hot/cold, day/night;

  • near synonyms, such as persuade/convince, goal/aim; and

  • closely related semantic sets, such as days of the week, colors, and items of clothing.

(Folse, 2004)

page.title: Integrate: Vocabulary
page.contents:
There are many different aspects to word meaning. It is not a good idea to learn them all at once; students should accumulate the different aspects of meaning over time.

Aspects of word meaning include at least

  • spelling,

  • pronunciation,

  • basic meaning,

  • L1 translation,

  • visual representation,

  • frequency of use,

  • common words that co-occur,

  • part of speech,

  • common forms (-ed, -ing, etc.), and

  • relationship to related words.

Students can use the Internet to collect aspects of meaning for vocabulary and keep them in a vocabulary notebook or make a mini-presentation to their class.

To Go Deeper


Read the article Vocabulary Notebooks: Theoretical Underpinnings and Practical Suggestions. It is available in the LINCS resource collection (go to https://lincs.ed.gov/professional-development/resource-collections/profile-768).

page.title: Optional Exploration: Vocabulary
page.contents:
Here are a few of the different web tools that are available for students to create vocabulary notecards or mini–vocabulary presentations. Take a look at several, and select the tools that would be most appropriate for a class that you teach.

Aspect of Meaning

Internet Tools

Basic meaning

Oxford Learner’s Dictionaries

http://www.oxfordlearnersdictionaries.com/us/

L1 translation

Google Translate

https://translate.google.com/

Pronunciation

Dictionary.com

http://dictionary.com

Spelling, part of speech, common forms

Longman Dictionary of Contemporary English

http://www.ldoceonline.com/

Visual representation

Bing image search

https://www.bing.com/images/

Common words that co-occur

Oxford online collocation dictionary

http://oxforddictionary.so8848.com/

page.title: Activity: Vocabulary
page.contents:
After reviewing several of the web tools, select three to five that are most appropriate for a class that you teach.

One way to make important links available to your students is to create a website on which to organize and display the links.

Making a website for a class of students is very easy and allows teachers to include the resources that they have picked out as being most useful for students.

The video demonstrates how to create a vocabulary website using weebly.com.

After watching the instructional video, create your own website and populate it with the vocabulary resources that you’ve selected as most appropriate for your students. Identify several units that most need additional vocabulary learning, and create one activity (e.g., vocabulary notebook or vocabulary mini-presentation) for vocabulary learning that can be used across the units that you identified.

page.title: Final Activity for Instructors
page.contents:
After having gone through all five of the skill areas, select the activity that you want to do.

You will be asked to identify the skill area and to enter information about the activity that you have designed to integrate into multiple units in one of your classes.

For your convenience, all the activities are included in a file linked here.

In your submission, you will be asked to report on the skill area that you selected from the list below.

  • Listening
  • Speaking
  • Reading
  • Writing
  • Vocabulary

How might you integrate digital literacy into your class, starting with one skill.

page.title: Final Activity for Administrators (for administrators)
page.contents:
After having gone through all five of the skill areas, it is time to think about the activity that you would like to complete if you were a teacher.

Think through what you would do and what teachers in your program might do.  

What barriers exist to you as you work to support integrating digital literacy into English language acquisition classes in your programs?

What factors provide support for teachers to integrate a new digital literacy activity into their adult English language acquisition classes?  

What skill area did you select for the final activity?

  • Listening
  • Speaking
  • Reading
  • Writing
  • Vocabulary

Consider how you might integrate digital literacy into your class, starting with one skill.

page.title: You have completed Unit 2
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-84.mp3

Audio transcript


Hopefully, the activity that you designed can be used as a way to integrate one type of digital literacy activity into your adult English language acquisition class. If you would like to learn more about integrating other aspects of digital literacy into your classes, you can participate in additional units in this module. Now that you have finished this professional development module unit, you may want to make sure that you have saved the links, resources, and notes that are important to you. Good luck with your next steps in integrating digital literacy into your adult English language instruction!

Congratulations! 

Thank you for participating in Unit 2 of Integrating Digital Literacy Into Adult English Language Instruction.

If you would like to learn more about integrating digital literacy into your classes, you can participate in additional units in this module.

  • Unit 1: Digital Literacy in Our lives

  • Unit 3: Digital Information Literacy

  • Unit 4: Solving Problems in Technology-Rich Environments

A list of further resources is available here.

You have reached the end of this lesson.  You may review any of the content in this lesson using the Lesson Menu on the left of the screen.

If you have finished viewing the lesson, (1) click the NEXT button on this screen to indicate completion in your progress tracker.  Then, (2) return to the home page to select your next activity.  Activities you have completed will be checked off in your progress tracker.
